newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil limits Anheuser-Busch, Antartica beer pact.
newsitem.headline: Brazil limits Anheuser-Busch, Antartica beer pact.

text.p: Brazil's anti-trust watchdog has set limits on an association between local brewer Antartica Paulista and the world's biggest brewer, Anheuser-Busch Cos Inc, an official said.
The official at Cade, the Administrative Economic Defense Council, said the two companies would have to dissolve their partnership in the Brazilian market in two years.
"The council reached a definitive decision yesterday (Wednesday), voting 5-2, that the association would have to be dissolved in two years," the official told Reuters.

The official added, however, that the council had indicated it could reevaluate its decision if Anheuser-Busch, brewer of Budweiser, and Antartica, Brazil's second largest brewer, altered some "anti-competition" clauses in their contract.
The Cade ruling echoed its decision in early June on a deal between South America's largest brewer Brahma and U.S giant Miller, a unit of Philip Morris Cos Inc.
The official said it was also "imaginable" that it would influence a decision expected soon on a pact between Carlsberg A/S and Skol Breweries Ltd.
He said the Anheuser-Antartica anti-competition clauses referred to included, among others, such items as price controls and exclusivity clauses.
Cade gave a preliminary ruling on the partnership a month ago.
Once a largely toothless body bossed around by the Finance Ministry, Cade has recently been flexing its muscles and vetoing major corporate mergers.
